articleContent.title: Our Goal
articleContent.alt: Sunrise landscape of a long and winding road
content: Hello there! We are a group of well-being enthusiasts who got degrees to learn more about the complexities of the human body. After years of client care we saw trends of preventable dysfunctions. We put our minds to work and realized the web was the best way to reach out to you. Our goal is to educate the public, so you can spend less time in a confining clinic and more time in a healthy body!

We believe research will never end and there are questions we cannot answer, but as experts in the field we have the responsibility to share our current leads and give you the basic facts. We will be thrilled to help you learn more about how to better care for your body.
Much love,
the KC team
articleContent.contentDetail: Lorem ipsum dolor sit, amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Numquam minus vitae aut rem explicabo doloribus.
articleContent.author: Kinesiology Collective

articleContent.title: The Rubber Band Chain Model
content: Our bodies are made up of many, many working parts. Sometimes we make the mistake of assuming our parts work individually to make the whole. This isn’t true. Our parts are interdependent on one another. We all know that if one person slacks in a team, then the whole team is affected. Before we learn anything it’s best we understand how our bodies move.

articleContent.author: Jenny Chung

articleContent.title: The Largest Muscle
content: Did you know your largest muscle is your gluteus maximus? That’s right. It’s the muscle you likely sit on every day. This means your glutes, short for gluteus maximus, are taxed with a massive responsibility.
articleContent.contentDetail: Lorem ipsum dolor sit, amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Numquam minus vitae aut rem explicabo doloribus.
articleContent.author: Jenny Chung

articleContent.title: Posture: A Root of Pain
articleContent.alt: Woman hunched over at her office
content: Growing up we were constantly pestered by the reminder to straighten up our backs. And for a very good reason. In our Rubber Band Chain Model article we explored the interdependent nature of our bodies. The consequences of good posture (or lack of it) will affect the parts down the chain.
articleContent.contentDetail: Lorem ipsum dolor sit, amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Numquam minus vitae aut rem explicabo doloribus.
articleContent.author: Jenny Chung

articleContent.title: Are Your Chores Ruining Your Back?
content: There are quite a bit of ways to befriend back pain and the way you do your chores could be one example. More precisely your posture can be causing that nagging back pain.

Take, for example, the dishes. If you’re anything like me and hate getting your clothes wet you’ll notice you stand away from and lean over the sink like a very gradual half arch. Depending on your sink placement relative to your arms you may or may not notice some back pain. But if you’re anything like me (again) standing at five feet tall, then you might notice while avoiding the wet (since my elbows are usually below and gravity works the drops down my arms) you step back to lean forward the distance of half a foot to the sink (to reach that darn faucet that’s another foot within the sink).
Analyze your dish washing position/posture we created a little math formula to find that golden ratio of you and sink (made with love).
